Quantum mechanics is a highly successful theory, but its foundations are still a matter of debate. In this paper, we propose a new set of axioms for quantum mechanics that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. We show that these axioms are sufficient to recover all the basic structures of quantum mechanics, including the algebra of observables, the state space, the evolution, and the measurement problem. Our approach is based on the notion of continuous linear maps between Hilbert spaces, which is a purely categorical concept. This provides a way to unify and extend many of the existing approaches to the foundations of quantum mechanics. Our work also has implications for the foundations of mathematics itself.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related species, Myxobolus cerebralis and Kudoa iwatai, and a less reduced cnidarian, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarians and are a highly reduced group in terms of genome size and gene content. These results provide insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. They also suggest that the Myxozoa are a model system for studying the evolution of parasitism. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel (Hv1) is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will make it more difficult to achieve food security. Here, we quantify the impact of climate change on the variability of maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of African herbivores. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and the extent to which they consumed grasses varied from >99% to <1%. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of species matched in body size and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of niche partitioning in the coexistence of large herbivores.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the US economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans, and those that do access them may not be able to repay them.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean has become a major concern. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of the smaller particles by a combination of processes, such as nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris in the ocean and highlights the need for further research to resolve the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased by a factor of 10. The expansion of the motorized fleet has been driven by the powered-artisanal fleet, which has grown by a factor of 10 since 1950. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous and the most important in terms of engine power, but it contributes only 27% of the global engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is one of the most important adaptations that animals can make. This study shows that the ability to do so is widespread and that it is associated with increased reproductive output. We show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather due to an increase in metabolic power. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output is the mother’s metabolic capacity rather than the availability of resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in synucleinopathies. This work opens the door for further preclinical and clinical studies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also the site of communication between cells. This communication is essential for the endothelium to control vascular function and is the focus of this study. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that are connected by short paths. This network is highly efficient in the transmission of signals and is able to rapidly respond to changes in the environment. These findings provide insight into the design of the endothelial network and the mechanisms by which it controls vascular function. They also have implications for understanding the role of the endothelium in health and disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, including signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

They are functionally coupled, and the activation gate is able to trigger the collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this functional coupling. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+ channel family. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is becoming increasingly clear, but the mechanisms by which the host and microbiome interact are not fully understood. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and compounds that could be used for drug development. These results support the idea that anaerobic gut fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, and the study of social hierarchy is a key component of social psychology. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with the risk of becoming subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance in rats. We also identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in reward processing and social behavior. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the material properties and the structure design. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct properties. The structures are digitally designed and then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are then assembled into architectures to enhance programmability. The structures are finally used to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors for various applications. The strategy can also be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with programmable behaviors under various external stimuli.

The hemoglobin system is a critical component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The hemoglobin proteins are encoded by two genes, alpha and beta, and are expressed in two distinct tissues, the red blood cell (RBC) and the megakaryocyte-derived platelet. The expression of the two hemoglobins is regulated in a developmental manner, with the fetal hemoglobin, HbF, being expressed in the fetus and newborn, and the adult hemoglobin, HbA, being expressed in the adult. The mechanisms that control the expression of the two hemoglobins are not fully understood. Here we show that a gene, IGF2BP1, is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is able to reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern in the erythroid lineage toward a more fetal-like pattern. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be involved in the regulation of the hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This effect is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we show that the combination of ferroptosis induction and mTORC1 inhibition is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These results suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease and the leading cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the stromal interaction molecule (STIM) Ca2+ channel complex, which is involved in store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE). Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of the plasma membrane ORAI channel. Our findings may help to develop new strategies for treating hypertension and cardiovascular diseases. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species, but not in reversing the decline of species associated with early-seral forests. Our results suggest that the NWFP has been successful in protecting older forests, but that the policy has not been effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. This is partly due to the fact that the NWFP did not protect enough older forests, and partly due to the continued decline of older forests from fire.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. We show that the predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The presented approach can be used to design new antibiotics for other targets and for other antibiotics. This work is a step toward the development of new antibiotics.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks can be very large, which can make it difficult to train the network, especially when the number of parameters is large. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture can be used in many image-processing problems in the future.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse and successful adaptive radiations in the history of life. The lake is one of the world’s largest freshwater ecosystems and is a critical component of the global hydrological cycle. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi. We show that the lake has been highly variable over the last 1.3 My, and that the shift in climate around 800,000 years ago was a critical threshold for the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime has important effects on sleep and alertness the next morning. Reading an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Ytterby meteorite, which fell in Sweden in 1739, is the only known source of the element osmium (Os). Os is a key element in the study of the YDB because of its high concentration in the ejecta and its preservation in the sediments. However, the origin of the Os in the YDB is still controversial. We show that the Os in the YDB is mostly of terrestrial origin, and that the Os in the meteorite is only a minor source of the Os in the YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the control of autoimmunity has been extensively studied, but the function of CTLA-4 in the maintenance of tolerance in the adult organism is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in the development of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be. We also show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in the thymus results in the development of myocarditis, which is not observed in the periphery. These results indicate that CTLA-4 is essential for the maintenance of tolerance in the adult organism.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is driven by the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and that the evolution of their diet is a key driver of beetle diversification.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to their epitope. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of new antibody-based therapeutics. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines, and may help to reduce the time and cost of antibody engineering. This work can also help to understand the impact of mutations on the epitope and may be useful in vaccine development.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to popular belief, population size does not enhance CCE. Instead, it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have important implications for the design of cultural evolution experiments and the interpretation of the results of such experiments. They also have implications for the design of societies in which individuals learn from one another.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated isoform. APOE is also highly associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which are the main cellular component of AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. We also suggest a hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with a higher rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, which are more vulnerable to complement-mediated neurodegeneration, and thus, may be a contributing factor to AD pathogenesis. This study reveals a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and it also suggests a hypothesis for the mechanism underlying the association between APOE and AD.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain’s response to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of modern humans, and understanding how the human brain processes language is a central goal of cognitive science. Here, we show that deep learning models of language processing in the brain are predictive of brain activity in response to spoken sentences, generalize across datasets, and correlate with model accuracy on a language task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that deep learning models may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in computer science, but it has not been used in scientific computing. We show that this is because of the instability of DL algorithms, which are used to train deep neural networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there is no algorithm that can train such a network. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limitations of deep learning in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with the necessary restrictions. One of the most prominent arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Here, we discuss the critical design flaws of this experiment and show that they are responsible for the widespread misinterpretation of the results. We argue that this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the non-neuromuscular form of leprosy known as lepromatous leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they have not lost the ability to cause disease.

The dynamics of quantum systems is a fundamental problem in physics. In this work, we study the dynamics of entanglement, which is a key resource in quantum information science. We show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems can be completely understood in the scaling limit of the time. This is a significant step toward a complete understanding of the dynamics of entanglement, which is a long-standing challenge.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This study describes a vaccine candidate that can be produced in large quantities and is highly protective against COVID-19.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or flea transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model fitting, which allows for the inclusion of uncertainty in the model parameters. This is particularly important for historical data, where the uncertainty in the data is often larger than in modern studies. Finally, this study shows that the use of a Bayesian approach can lead to a better understanding of the history of a disease.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity has been less studied. Here, we show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also more complex. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is characterized by four major shifts, which are associated with the evolution of birds and mammals. These shifts are important for understanding the evolution of brain size and the evolution of cognitive ability.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been the subject of intense investigation, but the function of this protein in mitochondria of normal cells has been unclear. Here we show that TRAP1 is a critical regulator of mitochondrial metabolism and function. In particular, TRAP1 promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin filaments are the building blocks of the cytoskeleton, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We propose that this ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a mechanism for how the mechanical state of the cytoskeleton can be used to control the activity of proteins involved in cell biology. This mechanism may be relevant to many cellular processes.

Fructose is the most common sweetener in the United States, but its effects on appetite and food intake are not well understood. This study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The settlement history is complex, and we find that the island was settled by multiple waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we find that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people’s emotions are transferred from others to them. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the emotional content of the Facebook News Feed is a powerful influence on people’s emotions, and that the design of the Facebook platform should be considered in light of this influence.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis. In addition to the protein-coding information encoded in the sequence of nucleotides, mRNAs can be modified posttranscriptionally. These modifications can have a variety of effects on the translation of the mRNA, including changing the rate of translation and the amino acid sequence of the protein. We show that the most common modification of mRNAs, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest effect on translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can alter the rate of translation and the amino acid sequence of the protein. This finding has implications for the function of mRNAs and the translation of the proteins they encode. (Show more)

This study shows that the subjective feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. This study also shows that this feeling is associated with positive changes in health and lifestyle over time. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging.

The evolution of body size is a central topic in biology. The aquatic mammals are a unique group of animals that have colonized the water and diversified, and thus provide a unique opportunity to examine the drivers of body size. We show that the evolution of aquatic mammals is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of body size and the potential for the aquatic environment to influence the evolution of body size and shape.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the leading cause of the common cold, and the ability to grow rhinovirus at cool nasal cavity temperature rather than at body temperature is a major advantage for the virus. We show that the mouse rhinovirus receptor, the RIG-I like receptor, is required for the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus. We also show that the mouse rhinovirus replicates more efficiently in the mouse than in the human airway, and that the mouse rhinovirus is more virulent in the mouse than the human rhinovirus. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies for the treatment of the common cold. The ability to sense the environment is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In bacteria, this process is often used to regulate the expression of virulence factors, which can be critical for the pathogenicity of the organism. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate the expression of virulence factors. This is a unique mechanism that allows bacteria to sense the mechanical activity of their own surface structures and to regulate their own surface-induced gene expression. This is an important mechanism for the pathogenicity of the organism.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the resulting contamination of surface waters is a global concern. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and the risk of exceeding regulatory threshold levels. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is widespread and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the animal reservoir of SARS-CoV-2 is a critical area of concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems associated with them, and some of the solutions. We also propose a new approach to hydropower that can be used to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. This approach is based on the integration of hydropower with other renewable energy sources, the use of innovative technologies, and the development of new business models.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of the plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type responsible for Aβ production, are also the source of the inflammatory response in AD. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and it may be a key factor in the development of AD.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in human history. However, the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens remains elusive. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the earliest known site of economic exploitation of chickens, Maresha, Israel. We show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period, and that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. Our results suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The study of the folding of individual proteins is complicated by the difficulty of measuring the structure of a single molecule in solution. Here we use a method that measures the structure of a single molecule in solution. We show that the folding of the large maltose binding protein is a two-step process, with a molecular intermediate that is the same for all molecules. The intermediate is a native-like structure that is adjacent to the native state in the sequence of the protein. The intermediate is a step on the folding pathway, and the pathway is not a single concerted process. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. They also provide a new method for studying protein folding.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also capable of removing the cap from transcripts that are not Np4-capped. This enzyme, which is normally inactive in the presence of disulfide stress, is able to recognize the cap on Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. This finding has implications for the ability of bacteria to rapidly adapt to stress by changing the expression of their genes. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function during sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also show that the biomass of humans has increased by a factor of 10 since the beginning of the Common Era. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Our results highlight the importance of humans in the global biomass of prominent taxa. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics. It is characterized by the fact that the system is in a critical state and that the system’s activity is self-regulated. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its bandgap is sensitive to temperature and pressure. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain without phonon instability. We also show that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned by strain, and that the bandgap can be made to vanish. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the nature of the metal–semiconductor transition in other materials.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. However, the role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of animals is less clear. Here, we show that the evolution of the immune system in animals is linked to the evolution of the immune system in bacteria. We also show that the immune system of animals evolved from the immune system of bacteria.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely to be a site of communication between the sexes. In this study, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these changes are likely to be important for sperm function. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is essential for blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain of VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that the binding is force sensitive. We also show that the force-sensitive binding can be used to trigger the binding reaction. This provides a mechanism for the observed gain of function of mutations in VWD. The results have implications for the pathophysiology of VWD and for the use of VWF as a therapeutic.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the role of viruses in human health has been much less studied. This study provides a comprehensive resource for human-associated viruses, and we find that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases. This resource will allow for the study of the role of viruses in human health and disease, and will be a valuable tool for the community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the interaction process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is able to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI process. The results show that the HSRL can provide significant contributions to the understanding of ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth, as well as for the habitability of the planet. The temperature of the surface has been inferred from isotopic data to have decreased over geological time, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record. Here, we present a method for reconstructing the temperature of the surface based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion flow. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of cell excitability and the maintenance of homeostasis. The K+ channel, BK, is one of the most important K+ channels in the heart. It is responsible for the regulation of the resting membrane potential and the cardiac contractility. The BK channel is unique in that it does not have an intracellular activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its rates and extents are inversely correlated with the channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 210 million cases and 435,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to bind to glycophorin A (GPA) on the surface of the RBC. We show that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the malaria parasite invasion process and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be completely opened, without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that induction of antiviral response is impaired in the lung of mice exposed to dry air, and that this dampened response contributes to disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. These insights may be useful for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to involve a tree-like structure of nested phrases, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s neural activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, and it is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

Vertebrate cells have two forms of Axin, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that regulate redundant genes and may be useful in the development of new therapeutics.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the LH, the GABA neurons, causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is critical for the development of this behavior, and that it is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity, and may be a target for the development of new treatments for this disease.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we report the development of a system for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agriculture, and could also be applied to other nitrogen-fixing systems, such as in the bioremediation of nitrogen-contaminated environments.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to monitor and deter deforestation, but the effectiveness of these systems is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize the source of sound. The auditory organs of animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global problems. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. In this study, we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and has the potential to be used in a vaccine.

The role of ALK in human cancer has been the focus of intense research. In the present study, we show that the zebrafish homologue of ALK, DrALK, is a ligand for zebrafish ALKALs. We show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are expressed in the neural crest and that loss of function of any of the three genes leads to a loss of iridophores, a pigment cell type derived from the neural crest. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKALS in neural crest development. This is the first report of a ligand–receptor system in a vertebrate.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present the first ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age, a period of time that has been poorly represented in the literature. Our results provide evidence for the existence of a single lineage of plague during this period, and suggest that the disease underwent a period of rapid dispersal across Eurasia. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a new perspective on the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the political behavior of men and women in the United States and around the world.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often in conflict with the need to maintain or increase SOC stocks. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on native grassland soils can be used to increase SOC storage and that this can be achieved without compromising crop productivity. This is a significant finding because it demonstrates that the management of agricultural lands can be climate-smart. The results of this study are particularly important for the United States, where the conversion of native grasslands to cropland is the largest source of SOC loss. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by developing a web tool, SpillOver, that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait for animals to detect it, but the mechanisms that plants use to produce colorful nectar are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of Nesocodon mauritianus nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the red color is selectively favored in the closely related Jaltomata herrerae, suggesting that this trait is under positive selection. Our findings provide evidence for convergent evolution of colorful nectar in two different plant–animal interactions. This work also demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. (Less)

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of migration and admixture processes. However, the genetic history of the continent during the period of cultural change from the 5th to the 7th century AD is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results provide insights into the demographic processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape. They also demonstrate the potential of genome-wide analysis to reveal unexpected aspects of the history of Europe.

The coronavirus MERS-CoV has caused ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. They also provide a basis for the development of vaccines and antivirals against MERS-CoV. Our study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of coronavirus infections and the development of new ones. This article is

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for the early detection of emerging pathogens and the rapid deployment of public health response. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid deployment of public health response.

The lagging strand of the double helix is synthesized by DNA polymerases in the presence of a sliding clamp. In humans, this clamp is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the PCNA-pol δ holoenzyme is critical for every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the holoenzyme in humans is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the holoenzyme. The results indicate that the holoenzyme maintains a loose association with the clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from the clamp on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the PCNA-pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. The RNA world is a hypothesized stage in the evolution of life, in which genetic information was stored in RNA molecules rather than in DNA. In this study, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template. This polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the development of in vitro life. (Show more)

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of neighborhoods in determining their future physical condition.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause damage to cells. The ability of fungi to bind and regulate copper is important for their survival in the environment and in the human body. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work demonstrates the existence of a previously unknown role for fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the ability of fungi to control the copper content of competing microbes. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of fungi in the human body and the environment. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) phase that is a product of high-temperature, low-pressure metamorphism. The discovery of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is significant because it suggests that the sedimentary rocks of the martian surface record the history of the planet.

Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors of plants and animals, and its impact on the performance of plants and animals is well known. However, despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. Here, we show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees. We also show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is affecting the performance of trees in different regions. Our findings can help land managers, foresters, and insurance companies to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IL-17 receptor. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the development of disease in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the most common cause is expansion of a single nucleotide in the gene for the RNA binding protein FUS. We report here a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. This allows rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This method will be useful for studying the role of astrocytes in ALS and for developing new therapies.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum alters the composition of the gut microbiota to facilitate its transmission. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of the pathogen. This study provides a mechanism for how pathogens can influence the composition of the microbiota to facilitate transmission. This work also provides a model for how pathogens can use host proteins to influence the microbiota. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. We show here that water vapor plays an important role in the climate system, and that it is important to understand the role of water vapor in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. In some species, the presence of high concentrations of a pigment called biliverdin causes the animal to appear blue-green. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads), and that the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin is the main driver of this evolution. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This work also provides a new tool for studying the function of serpin proteins. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a key feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the proportion of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs). This increase in BCSCs is associated with increased tumorigenicity and resistance to chemotherapy. Thus, our findings suggest that targeting ALKBH5 may be a strategy for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This paper reports the results of a study of 465 parchment samples, including 72 pocket Bibles, using a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of the parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. The results suggest that ultrafine parchment does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is uncertain, but the evidence points to a combination of factors, including global environmental perturbation, carbon cycle disruption, and a pulse of mass extinction. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the timing of the trigger and kill mechanisms, and to evaluating the plausibility of the trigger mechanisms. The age model presented here is based on the precise dating of volcanic ash beds, which are the only reliable chronostratigraphic markers for the Permian-Triassic boundary.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive immune response against the intestinal microbiota. The intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) are the first line of defense against the invasion of pathogens and the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis. However, the excessive immune response in IBD leads to the destruction of the intestinal barrier, which is the main cause of the development of IBD. Here, we demonstrate that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the cellular receptor, and show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion with the target membrane.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
