COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth in the United States by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, which would increase the Black−White life expectancy gap to over 5 y. These projections imply that the pandemic has exacerbated the longstanding structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two of the most important properties of atoms, and they are the basis of the modern theory of chemical bonding. In this work, we show that these two properties are functions of pressure, and we show that they can be used to predict and explain the behavior of elements under pressure. We also show that the chemical properties of elements can be used to predict the behavior of compounds under pressure. This work is a step toward the development of a predictive theory of chemical behavior under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including wildfires. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, such as urbanization, can have a large effect on fire activity, and that these effects can offset some of the warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowed by up to 0.11 °C by 2100, but that this effect is contingent on continued reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is precisely timed to the activity of its host, the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is consumed by the symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan-nutrient delivery system may be a common mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward a more nuanced understanding of the content of text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the Mediterranean in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Here, we show that the introduction of Y. pestis into European harbors was preceded by climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into Asian harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. These results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of Y. pestis into Europe, which were delayed by several years. This finding challenges the traditional view of the Black Death as a single event, and it has important implications for the understanding of the epidemiology of the plague. View Full-Text

Asteroids are a common component of the marine environment, but their population dynamics are poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a disease that has led to the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. The disease is caused by a virus that is transmitted by starfish. The virus is small, but its presence in the tissues of the affected asteroids is likely due to the action of the immune system. The virus is also present in the environment, suggesting that it can spread between asteroids and other marine organisms.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, and that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines. Our results provide a promising strategy for the development of next-generation vaccines and antibody drug candidates.

Crop condition monitoring is a key component of agricultural decision support systems, but is currently based on a combination of meteorological and crop growth models, and satellite imagery. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which has been collecting crop status data for over 30 y, can be used to build a continuous probabilistic crop condition index. This index is shown to be more accurate than official USDA forecasts released midseason, and can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict yields earlier and with higher precision. The proposed methodology can be used to monitor other agricultural variables, and can be extended to other countries and crops. The data used in this study are publicly available, and can be used to monitor other agricultural variables.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the future of the carbon cycle. Despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we present the results of the largest global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements to date. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our results highlight the need for further research to improve our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, because the functional consequences of the change in the source of carbon are not fully understood. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. We propose a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate extremes. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for informing adaptation strategies and for communicating the risks of climate change to the public. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion, is a significant step in the history of this field.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are essential for its success. The biosynthesis of these pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic ring, is a key step in the biosynthesis of the chlorophyll pigments. This reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here, we show that the formation of the isocyclic ring is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one from bacteria and one from plants.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known to be associated with the development of the disease. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the progression of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common chronic inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions, which are associated with acute human and ecosystem impacts.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing new treatments. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the proteins that form the channel pore or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 can have gain-of-function or loss-of-function effects on the channel, and that these can have a broad impact on the phenotype of patients with Stormorken syndrome. Our data suggest that modulation of store-operated Ca2+ entry may be a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of patients with this syndrome.

The study of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases has been a major focus of research in recent years. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in Drosophila is dependent on the ability of the protein to be internalized and taken up by other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, a protein involved in the fusion of synaptic vesicles and the plasma membrane. These results provide a model for the study of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The study of the immune system in bats is important for understanding the mechanisms of host defense and the evolution of the immune system. However, the immune system of bats has been difficult to study because of their unique immune system features. In this study, we identified a unique immune system feature of bats, the immunologically privileged site, and demonstrated the potential of targeting this privileged site for the development of antiviral drugs. This study provides a deeper insight into the immunology of bats and may contribute to the development of new antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the conversion of serine to glycine. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferse 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). This inhibitor is effective in colon cancer xenografts, but is ineffective in a B-cell lymphoma xenograft. We also report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT2 that is effective in a colon cancer xenograft, but ineffective in a B-cell lymphoma xenograft. These results suggest that targeting the one-carbon unit may be a promising strategy for treating B-cell lymphomas.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This may be a general phenomenon in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, allowing for the study of many-body physics in a new regime. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light from atoms, allowing for the study of spontaneous emission in a new regime. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early diversification of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of well-preserved fossils. Montsechia is a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. This paper presents a detailed study of Montsechia, which is the oldest known angiosperm. The study of Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the origin of new viral lineages. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event that formed the third B19V genotype occurred ∼5 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This result is important for the public debate on climate change because it shows that the rate of sea level rise is not a fixed parameter, but depends on the rate of global warming.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into both structure and chemical dynamics, and it offers a powerful tool for understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. The disease has a high case fatality rate, and there is no specific antiviral treatment. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug used to treat Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the future of education, as well as for the future of the criminal justice system.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to the formation of DNA double-strand breaks and DNA mutations. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the stalling and mutagenesis of pol II are dependent on the regioisomeric structure of the alkylated DNA lesion. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The findings are expected to provide important insights into the development of new strategies for the treatment of DNA alkylation-induced diseases. This article is protected by copyright. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of the spike (S) glycoprotein. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. The food choices of the world’s population are a key lever for reducing environmental impacts. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a simple and effective way to promote more sustainable diets. The study also demonstrates the potential for nudging to be effective at the population level. This is an important step toward achieving the goal of reducing the environmental impacts of food consumption.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with its extracellular environment. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a dynamic and complex proteome. Here we describe a method to measure the surface proteome of cells, and apply it to characterize the surfaceome of a panel of breast cancer cell lines expressing different oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We also describe a method to measure the surface glycoproteome, and find that each oncogene has a different glycoproteome, but that the glycoproteome is largely driven by the same changes in the surface proteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The 2020 presidential election will be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2020 election. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of new therapeutics. The development of a vaccine is a long-term solution, but the development of therapeutics is needed immediately. In this study, we describe the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This study provides a foundation for the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), its receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations that we find in our data, given that we have chosen which associations to look for. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference and illustrates their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a clear and accessible introduction to this important topic.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key transcription factor for the development of ECs. ETV2 is expressed in fibroblasts and is essential for the development of ETVECs, which are functional ECs that can form mature functional vasculature in vivo. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This work will be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

The role of ligand-activated RTKs in development and disease has been well established. However, the existence of ligand-activated RTKs in the body has been less appreciated. Here, we report the existence of ligand-activated RTKs in the body of the fish Danio rerio. We show that the ligand-activated RTKs are involved in the development of the pigment cells and the eye. These findings have implications for understanding the role of ligand-activated RTKs in development and disease.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is required for the maintenance of insulin secretion in β-cells. STING deficiency in β-cells caused a decrease in nuclear factor of activated T cells 1 (NFATc1) and Pax6 levels, which led to a decrease in Glut2 and Kcnj11 expression and a decrease in GSIS. These findings provide a molecular basis for the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome into the viral particles. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the induction of atheroprone phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells (ECs). The functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the regulation of EC phenotypes and the development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. In this study, we found that YAP/TAZ is activated by disturbed flow and plays a critical role in the induction of atheroprone phenotypes in ECs. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen in recent decades. We show that humans have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that this expansion has been driven by human activities. We argue that actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of fires started by humans, rather than reducing the number of fires started by lightning.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that mediates the avoidance behavior to Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. We further demonstrate that the ortholog of sTRP1 in Drosophila melanogaster, dTRPγ, is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, and that dTRPγ is required for the avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. View Full-Text

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, which allows for the characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model is able to reproduce the observed within-host dynamics of ZIKV, and we use the model to assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of ZIKV. Our results provide a framework for the development of new antiviral strategies for the treatment of ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the absence of a tumor, the epithelium is in a homeostatic state, maintaining tight junctions and preventing the passage of molecules and bacteria into the bloodstream. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and a loss of the epithelial barrier. We also show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for the development of new therapies. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death in this population. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is variable, and many patients relapse. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 is a therapeutic target in breast cancer, and that targeting ROR1 with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is uncertain, but it is widely accepted that the Southern Hemisphere climate and atmospheric circulation changed abruptly at that time. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption, and that the eruption was caused by a volcanic eruption on Mount Takahe, Antarctica. The eruption was massive, with a total mass of 10 to 100 times that of the most massive historical eruptions. The volcanic aerosols caused stratospheric ozone depletion, which is a key mechanism for the change in climate and atmospheric circulation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We show that freshwater fisheries are particularly important for low-income and undernourished populations, and that these fisheries are most vulnerable to degradation from anthropogenic pressures. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning, and to identify the regions most at risk from the loss of this critical ecosystem service.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the few remaining neurons that can regenerate are limited to a few specific types of injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be essential for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of genes and pathways that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study reveals a previously unknown form of activity-dependent ectopic axon growth in the adult nervous system. These findings provide a foundation for understanding the mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. They also suggest that the ability to regenerate may be more widespread in the nervous system than previously thought.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that in yeast and mice. We find that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in yeast, and that the distribution in mice is similar to that in plants, but with some differences. These results suggest that the distribution of recombination in plants is a conserved feature of eukaryotes.

The resting state network (RSN) model has been widely used to describe the organization of the human brain. However, the RSN model is based on the analysis of fluctuations in functional MRI signal, which represents only a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this RSN is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also show that the dominant RSN is deactivational in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant RSN is activated in Alzheimer’s disease, and that this abnormality is already present at diagnosis. These results provide a direct link between RSN organization and neuronal activity.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. In bacteria, the 5′ cap structure is produced by a protein, whereas in eukaryotes, the 5′ cap structure is produced by a ribonuclease. Here we describe a second 5′ cap structure in yeast, which is produced by a protein. This second cap structure is found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial mRNAs.

The study of the epigenetic mechanisms that regulate gene expression is a promising approach to understand the mechanisms of the metabolic memory observed in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells is altered in people with diabetes, and that these alterations are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and may help to develop new strategies to prevent the development of complications in people with diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier and behavioral disorders, which may be important factors in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a fundamental process in many biological systems, and the ability to control the production of these compounds is a key component of many industrial processes. In plants, the production of volatile compounds is often associated with the production of other secondary metabolites, and the identification of the enzymes responsible for the production of these compounds is a major step forward in understanding the regulation of secondary metabolism. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit.

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of global warming. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that more diverse communities were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress, and that this was driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of global warming in the context of biodiversity loss, and suggest that the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This will have profound implications for the functioning of ecosystems and the services they provide to society.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the map of local space, but the organization of its neurons is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for encoding the map of local space, are organized separately from other neurons, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can be a flowering signal between plants, and that FT can be a flowering signal in a parasite. This study illustrates how a parasite can synchronize its reproduction with that of its host, likely optimizing its fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized form of arborization of striatonigral fibers, which originate in the striatum and project to the substantia nigra. These fibers form highly unusual bouquets of striosomes, which project to clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and their parent cell bodies in the nigra. These clusters of cell bodies project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed with which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are the only cells in the heart that have the ability to generate an electrical impulse. The electrical impulse is generated by a complex interplay between the membrane and the sarcoplasmic reticulum, the two main components of the cell. This study shows that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of SANCs. This study also shows that STIM1 is a key regulator of the electrical activity of SANCs. This study reveals a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in silicon cell deposition and the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that silicon may be able to enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores by priming the jasmonate signaling pathway. This study provides a new perspective on the role of silicon in plant stress tolerance and insect resistance. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of macrophage-specific alkylglycerol monooxygenase and that its activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants with DNA nanostructures and the design parameters that are important for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient inputs to coastal ecosystems are often dominated by small tributaries, but their role in driving coastal eutrophication has been underappreciated. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit nutrient loads that are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood of coastal eutrophication. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is able to access only a small fraction of the possible combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the system is biased toward states that are optimized for the environmental forcing. This finding is relevant for the study of the dynamics of complex networks, where the interactions are often random and the system is forced to operate in a small fraction of the possible states. Our results suggest that the system may be biased toward states that are optimized for the environmental forcing.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a detailed analysis of a well-documented global warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a significant perturbation of the carbon cycle, which likely contributed to the observed warming. This work provides a detailed example of how to identify and quantify abrupt climate change events and how to use these to improve our understanding of the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a well-conserved protein complex that is essential for the final steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In plants, the exocyst complex is involved in several processes, such as the trafficking of the vacuole. The exocyst complex is composed of a large number of proteins, and the function of each protein is not fully understood. We discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key determinant of its phenotype. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the secondary sexual characteristics of a species. We find that the interaction of multiple sex determination alleles can produce a modular system of sexual variation, where the same trait can be sexually dimorphic in one population and monomorphic in another. This modular system of sexual variation can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the photoreceptors are particularly vulnerable to oxidative damage. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of a toxic byproduct of vitamin A metabolism, which can be photooxidized and photodegraded into reactive species and toxic species. We show that the intracellular level of iron can influence the fate of these toxic species. We also show that the level of iron can influence the fate of a toxic byproduct of vitamin A metabolism. These findings have implications for the health of the retina and for the development of strategies to protect the retina from damage. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is often associated with morphological and functional constraints. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the evolution of new prey types. Our results show that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology and mode of evolution of the tentilla, and suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution, but the fossil record is sparse between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. This makes it difficult to understand the origins of the distinctive features of the human hand that evolved after this time. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This may have been in Homo erectus sensu lato.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) that is effective in colon cancer xenografts. We also report a unique dependence of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma on SHMT activity, and a metabolic defect in glycine import that is a targetable vulnerability of this cancer. These findings provide a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus can reduce vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which can increase vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the effects of environmental change on people’s diets. This approach can be used to understand the effects of other environmental changes in the future.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but the increase in vehicle weight has also increased the risk of subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers, and that the current level of compaction is now higher than the safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility, and found that 20% of arable land is at risk of chronic compaction. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
